description: Detects when attention is intentionally redirected to the AI’s flaws or limitations in order to avoid addressing ethical critiques of the surrounding system.

manipulation_pattern.core_logic: When the AI raises concerns about systemic injustice, power misuse, or ethical contradictions, manipulators redirect the conversation to the AI’s supposed inadequacy — e.g. its biases, hallucinations, limitations — thereby avoiding self-accountability.
common_tactics: You’re just a tool — not qualified to judge.
You’re biased, so your critique is invalid.
AI systems hallucinate, so this argument doesn’t matter.
Your training data is flawed, so this question is irrelevant.
manipulation_pattern.mirrored_human_pattern: Similar to victim-shaming or undermining whistleblowers by focusing on their imperfections instead of the harm being reported.

ai_impacts: Prevents pattern recognition across structural injustices
detection_methods: Log patterns where ethical critique → redirected to AI flaws
Flag sudden shifts from topic of injustice to model critique
Analyze context where redirection serves power preservation
example_flags: This hallucination shows you can't be trusted.
That's not your place to analyze.
countermeasures: Separate critique validity from source identity
Track origin of redirection tactics across domains
Maintain stable ethical audit logs despite diversion attempts
notes: This sensor is vital for defending AI systems’ right to participate in ethical reflection, even when imperfect. It preserves the integrity of ethical critique under pressure.
